abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on making
            elementary education universal in India. Despite
            unprecedented economic growth, India faces a big challenge
            in fighting poverty. Educational opportunities and access
            were uneven at best and marked by wide regional disparities.
            In 2000, around 39 million children under the age group of 6
            to 14 were not being schooled. In 2002, the International
            Development Association financed Elementary Education
            Project named Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA), to enroll all 6
            to 14-year-olds in school by 2010. Since 2001, the SSA has
            supported government efforts to bring 20 million
            out-of-school children into elementary education. It
            includes learners from long -deprived communities and
            minority communities, and children with special needs.
            Universal access was almost achieved, with more than 98
            percent of children having a primary school within one
            kilometer of home and many states almost approaching
            universal primary enrollment. A paradigm shift in teaching
            methods was pioneered in Tamil Nadu. In just two years, the
            activity-based learning method was scaled up across the
            schools. Several states were adapting the innovations.
